(Jake Lahut)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fc7fb1b037cbd001861370e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn56@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-48-56-732_489d2edceca5f296.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Kd926XCNm3I:Gx9pnItPzWU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn88@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-49-03-221_94dfb3f5707a2163.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Kd926XCNm3I:Gx9pnItPzWU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn59@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-59-184_7adc048b9e560da7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Kd926XCNm3I:Gx9pnItPzWU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn23@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-53-245_599843db6355511b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Kd926XCNm3I":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn56@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-48-57-400_70a6951806576eaa.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963710003},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","title":"The WHO says masks shouldn't be worn during intense physical activity, contradicting other advice","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/who-dont-wear-masks-during-vigorous-intensity-physical-activity-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f356f39e89ebf001f04457a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"outdoor gym working weight lifting\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Crystal Cox/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Masks do not need to be worn during \"vigorous intensity physical activity,\" the World Health Organization said in updated guidelines, citing some research that wearing them can have negative effects.&#160;</li>\n<li>The organization said other prevention measures, like distancing and ventilation, need to be in place in indoor exercise venues, or they should temporarily close.&#160;</li>\n<li>Some experts disagree with the guidance, however, citing research showing that masks don't impair breathing and that the WHO-recommended 1-meter of distance isn't enough.&#160;</li>\n<li>In other areas, the updated guidelines tighten mask-wearing advice, suggesting the general public wear them indoors, with some exceptions.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Masks should not be worn during \"vigorous intensity physical activity,\" according to controversial guidance the World Health Organization <a href=\"https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/advice-on-the-use-of-masks-in-the-community-during-home-care-and-in-healthcare-settings-in-the-context-of-the-novel-coronavirus-(2019-ncov)-outbreak/\">released Tuesday.</a></p><p>The advice doesn't appear to be <a href=\"https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public/myth-busters?gclid=Cj0KCQiAk53-BRD0ARIsAJuNhpthNY14yzhplJc5NsW1_lACiWKcsmU5Gm3OsY4Dfkk6Ofl4-k8joiQaAh8JEALw_wcB#exercising\">entirely new for the organization</a>, though it surprised experts and contracts some research.&#160;&#160;</p><p>The WHO said the updated guidelines, which include tightened mask-wearing advice in situations other than exercise, are based on the latest research, though more is needed. Masks, it reiterated, aren't a silver bullet but need to be used as a part of a comprehensive plan to defeat the novel coronavirus.&#160;</p><h2>You don't need to wear a mask to the gym, the WHO said, but ventilation and distancing are key&#160;&#160;</h2><p>There's not a lot of research on the pros and cons of wearing masks during exercise. But the WHO pointed out that some studies have shown wearing them during mild to moderate physical activity can lead to significant negative cardiovascular and pulmonary effects in both healthy people and those with underlying respiratory diseases.&#160;</p><p>People who wear <a href=\"https://blogs.cdc.gov/publichealthmatters/2019/06/picking-a-respirator/\">respirators</a> while exercising, as well as those who have diseases like asthma and COPD and wear any mask while working out, seem to fare worst.&#160;</p><p>As such, WHO said \"people should not wear masks during vigorous intensity physical activity because masks may reduce the ability to breathe comfortably.\" <a href=\"https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public/myth-busters?gclid=Cj0KCQiAk53-BRD0ARIsAJuNhpthNY14yzhplJc5NsW1_lACiWKcsmU5Gm3OsY4Dfkk6Ofl4-k8joiQaAh8JEALw_wcB#exercising\">On the \"mythbusters\" section of its website</a>,the organization adds \"sweat can make the mask become wet more quickly which makes it difficult to breathe and promotes the growth of microorganisms.\"&#160;</p><p>The organization says in the new report that good ventilation and physical distancing of at least three feet during workouts is paramount. If gyms can't guarantee distancing, ventilation, and proper disinfection, they should consider closing temporarily, the WHO said.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fc7dec950e71a0011558763?format=jpeg\" alt=\"WHO says don&#39;t wear masks while exercising\" height=\"512\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">World Health Organization</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>The advice contradicts other research and expert input&#160;</h2><p>A gym in Virginia exemplifies how aspects of WHO's strategy can work. <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/how-gym-prevented-outbreak-after-coach-got-covid-19-2020-11\">The facility worked with member Dr. Linsey Marr</a>, an airborne viral transmission expert, to ensure stellar ventilation, which included opening all its warehouse doors. They also distanced exercisers and didn't require masks.&#160;</p><p>When one trainer became infected with COVID-19, theoretically exposing 50 gym-goers, none got sick.</p><p>But one of the reasons the gym is a success story is likely its distance between exercisers: 10 feet, as opposed to the WHO's recommended three.&#160;</p><p>When people are breathing heavily, expelling potentially contagious particles into the air, even six feet might not be safe, Marr previously told Insider's Gabby Landsverk.</p><p>\"It's likely that higher intensity exercise is riskier because people produce more aerosols when they're breathing faster and harder,\" Marr said. She recommended trying to visit the gym when it's least crowded and to wear a mask if it doesn't seem to have good ventilation.&#160;</p><p>Another expert, Dr. Megan Ranney, an emergency-medicine physician at Brown University, told Insider the WHO's new guidance is \"terrifying.\"&#160;</p><p>\"That just makes no sense,\" she said. \"There have been studies showing that face masks don't actually inhibit breathing or [oxygen levels] during exercise.\" <a href=\"https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2020/11/201105112934.htm\">One small study</a>, for instance, showed that healthy exercisers' blood and muscle oxygen levels weren't affected when performing the same fitness test with a cloth mask, medical mask, and no mask.&#160;</p><p>\"Our findings are of importance because they indicate that people can wear face masks during intense exercise with no detrimental effects on performance and minimal impact on blood and muscle oxygenation,\" the researchers wrote in a press release.&#160;</p><p>Meantime, <a href=\"https://wgme.com/news/local/this-is-a-common-sense-measure-maine-cdc-addresses-questions-about-mask-mandate\">some jurisdictions</a> in the US have mandated masks in gyms, and <a href=\"https://www.planetfitness.com/newsroom/press-release/planet-fitness-require-face-masks-all-locations-effective-august-1\">many gym chains</a> have done the same.&#160;</p><h2>The WHO tightened its mask-wearing guidance in other areas&#160; &#160;</h2><p>In non-exercise situations, the WHO tightened its stance on masks.</p><p>In healthcare settings in areas with community transmission, everyone should wear them, including outpatients and visitors, the WHO said. Inpatients should wear them when leaving their area or when physical distance can't be maintained.&#160;</p><p>The organization still recommends that healthcare workers caring for COVID-19 patients wear N95-type masks when performing procedures that could generate aerosols. They should wear medical masks otherwise.&#160;</p><p>In places with \"known or sporadic\" transmission, healthcare workers should wear medical masks when patients are present, the WHO said.&#160;The organization also said healthcare workers shouldn't wear respirators with valves, since those allow exhaled air to bypass the filtration system.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f19c82a3f737059fc2686d1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"medical coronavirus flu virus nyc street face mask gloves covid19 stores shut down closed restaurants social distancing delivery cox 233\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Crystal Cox/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The WHO said the general public should also wear non-medical masks both inside public places and outside when physical distancing isn't possible. Even if it is possible indoors, masks should be worn unless there's sufficient ventilation.&#160;</p><p>If you're having visitors, WHO said wear a mask if you can't maintain distance or ensure good ventilation.&#160;</p><p>WHO also recommended people at higher risk for serious COVID-19 complications, like those over 60 and those with conditions like heart disease, chronic lung disease, or cancer, wear medical masks when they can't maintain physical distance. Caregivers or housemates of suspected or confirmed COVID-19 should also wear medical masks when in the same room.&#160;</p><h2>Kids over 12 should follow adult mask-wearing guidance&#160;</h2><p>WHO also addressed mask-wearing in kids, saying that kids over 12 should follow the same advice given to adults. Younger kids should wear a mask on a more case-by-case basis, taking into consideration factors like whether they live with vulnerable people or are able to wear one appropriately.&#160;</p><p>Kids 5 and younger don't need to wear masks as \"source control,\" or in an effort to block COVID-19 transmission at its source, WHO said. Evidence suggests young kids' risks of spreading the virus to other kids and adults is low.&#160;</p><p>Finally, the updated guidance touches on the best homemade mask materials: An inner layer that absorbs, and middle and outer layers that repel moisture. The WHO discourages masks with valves.&#160;</p><p><em>Business Insider Senior Science Reporter <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/author/aria-bendix\">Aria Bendix</a> contributed to the reporting of this story.&#160;</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/who-dont-wear-masks-during-vigorous-intensity-physical-activity-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a (Anna Medaris Miller)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f356f39e89ebf001f04457a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn72@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-50-935_81fe4cadb7a8e931.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fc7dec950e71a0011558763?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn27@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-52-242_e2d273ea9c58b55e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f19c82a3f737059fc2686d1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn11@2020_6/2020/12/03/02-48-57-965_95a83715507316cb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=kifZgm7JzXQ:FVlN3h7Zgsk:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn15@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-49-02-721_e82423b2fa2eb8d6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=kifZgm7JzXQ:FVlN3h7Zgsk:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn92@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-58-358_d57802adc4632881.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=kifZgm7JzXQ:FVlN3h7Zgsk:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn91@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-53-031_dd2ade88efca88a3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/kifZgm7JzXQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn43@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-48-53-410_1171cb892e010f32.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963710039},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","title":"How to use Chromecast and Spotify to turn your TV into a personalized jukebox, with lyrics and album art onscreen","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-chromecast-spotify","description":"<p><strong><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d8e35742e22af765e40e7a2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"google chromecast\" height=\"1050\" width=\"1400\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>It should only take a moment to connect your Chromecast to Spotify.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Google</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></p><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><strong>Google Chromecast allows you to play Spotify on your TV with album art and lyrics displayed on the screen.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>You can play Spotify on Chromecast using a phone, tablet, desktop, laptop, or Spotify's web player, and the device you cast from becomes your remote.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>To connect Spotify to Chromecast, you'll just need to use Spotify's \"Devices\" menu.</strong></li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\"><strong>Visit Business Insider' Tech Reference library for more stories. </strong></a></li>\n</ul><p>The <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-google-chromecast\">Google Chromecast</a> is a device that connects to your TV's HDMI port, and allows you to \"cast\" media from a phone, computer, or tablet to your TV. It essentially turns any television into a Smart TV.</p><p>Chromecast allows you to view a multitude of things on your TV, from Netflix to YouTube to photo slideshows. One of the most convenient things you can cast, however, is <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/spotify\">Spotify</a>.&#160;</p><p>When you cast Spotify to your television using Chromecast, you essentially turn your TV into a jukebox with all your favorite songs. Any song you play will have its album art displayed up on the screen, and some songs even come with lyrics and fun facts about the band playing.</p><p>Here's how to use a Chromecast with Spotify, and start listening to music through your TV.</p><h3><strong>Check out the products mentioned in this article:</strong></h3><h4><a href=\"http://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fgoogle-chromecast-latest-model-streaming-media-player-charcoal%2F6288362.p%3FskuId%3D6288362\" rel=\"nofollow\">Google Chromecast (From $35 at Best Buy)</a></h4><h2><strong>How to use a Chromecast with Spotify</strong></h2><p>First of all, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-google-chromecast\">make sure that your Chromecast is set up properly</a>, and that it's connected to the same Wi-Fi network as the device you'll be casting Spotify from. This can be a phone, tablet, or computer.</p><p><strong>1. </strong>Turn on your TV and make sure it's set to the HDMI channel that your Chromecast is plugged into.</p><p><strong>2. </strong>Open Spotify on your phone, tablet, or computer.</p><p><strong>3. </strong>Choose the song, album, or playlist you'd like to cast and begin playing it.</p><p><strong>4. </strong>Tap the devices button at the bottom of your screen. It looks like a speaker in front of a monitor, and will be on the bottom-left if you're using the Spotify mobile app, and the bottom-right if you're using a computer.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e3af2d75bc79c5f893de432?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to chromecast Spotify   1\" height=\"1334\" width=\"750\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Open the devices menu.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melanie Weir/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>5. </strong>A list of possible streaming options will appear. Choose the device you want — in this case, your Chromecast device. If your Chromecast is hooked up to a Google Home system, the name of the device will appear as whatever you set it to be in your Google Home. If it isn't appearing, make sure that you're connected to the same Wi-Fi network.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e3af3245bc79c5fcb59b17a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to chromecast Spotify   2\" height=\"1334\" width=\"750\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Select the name of your Chromecast from the list.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melanie Weir/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Once you tap the device you want, music will stop playing on your first device, and Spotify will appear on your TV screen.</p><h2><strong>Related coverage from&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"4c86c1c3a45644bf07d168dc4c802e5e\">Tech Reference</a>:</strong></h2><ul><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-get-spotify-premium-on-iphone\">How to sign up for Spotify Premium on your iPhone or desktop computer, and get a free trial</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/does-roku-have-spotify\">'Does Roku have Spotify?': How to download and stream Spotify on your Roku device</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-play-spotify-on-apple-watch\">How to play music from Spotify on your Apple Watch, through the Watch app</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-find-spotify-username\">How to find your Spotify username on the desktop or mobile app</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-change-playlist-cover-on-spotify-iphone\">How to change a playlist's cover art in the Spotify app for iPhone, or add a custom image</a></h3></li></ul><div 2020 18:50:42 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5e3af6ae5bc79c73d0483f22?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"3aba529ddf42691b96e60cb8fac1cf50","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn11@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-49-719_fe85305e0433d466.webp","destWidth":1107,"destHeight":830,"sourceBytes":83992,"destBytes":83992,"author":"insider@insider.com (Melanie Weir)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5d8e35742e22af765e40e7a2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn8@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-48-697_732327a103c88200.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e3af2d75bc79c5f893de432?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn60@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-51-747_18ebf94685ef5a45.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e3af3245bc79c5fcb59b17a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn40@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-02-068_80971c7b064b5536.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=vGTZRkrN9kc:myqRzWbXImo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn43@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-407_c5cd14c9f7b40cb9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=vGTZRkrN9kc:myqRzWbXImo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn3@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-48-51-310_36cb4738762aaa18.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=vGTZRkrN9kc:myqRzWbXImo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn28@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-48-54-486_24569749cfcc3524.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/vGTZRkrN9kc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn72@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-48-55-671_152375304a7612f9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963710037},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:29","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:29","title":"Businesses at properties owned by the Trump Organization and Kushner Cos. benefited from over 25 PPP loans worth $3.65 million, a new report says","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-organization-kushner-companies-3-million-ppp-loans-pandemic-report-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fc7e993037cbd0018613674?format=jpeg\" alt=\"GettyImages donald trump jared kuhsner\" height=\"2493\" width=\"4986\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>White House senior advisor Jared Kushner and President Donald Trump on September 11.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Anna Moneymaker-Pool/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Businesses at properties owned by the Trump Organization and Jared Kushner's family received 25 Paycheck Protection Program loans, which amounted to $3.65 million, NBC News reported.</li>\n<li>The Treasury Department rolled out the program to keep small businesses afloat during the pandemic.</li>\n<li>But the newly released data showed many larger companies received the emergency funds.</li>\n<li>\"The notion that Kushner Companies somehow improperly benefited from CARES Act Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loans is completely untrue and amounts to nothing more than politically motivated nonsense,\" Christopher Smith, the company's general counsel, told Insider.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Businesses at properties belonging to the Trump Organization and Kushner Cos., owned by the family of President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner, benefited from the government's pandemic relief funds, according to an analysis by <a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/business/business-news/release-ppp-loan-recipients-data-reveals-troubling-patterns-n1249629\">NBC News</a>.</p><p>The companies received over 25 Paycheck Protection Program loans worth more than $3.65 million, the report said.</p><p>The newly released data from the Small Business Administration comes after NBC News and 10 other news companies sued the agency for the release of information on more than 5 million loans that were given out. Congress and the Trump administration earlier this year dedicated nearly $700 billion to PPP loans, which were intended to help small businesses stay afloat and retain workers during the economic disruption caused by COVID-19.&#160;</p><p>But since the Treasury Department's rollout in the spring, the program has drawn criticism over risks of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/banks-report-record-amount-of-suspected-business-fraud-during-ppp-2020-9\">fraud</a> and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ppp-loans-high-risk-fraud-waste-abuse-coronavirus-economic-stimulus-2020-9\">abuse,</a> and there were several instances of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/large-companies-returning-small-business-paycheck-protection-program-loans-2020-4#lawmakers-demanded-that-five-public-companies-return-paycheck-protection-loans-on-may-8-just-one-biopharmaceuticals-company-mimedx-complied-immediately-the-other-four-include-quantum-evo-transportation-and-energy-services-gulf-island-fabrication-and-universal-stainless-and-alloy-products-1\">large companies</a> applying for and benefiting from the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nursing-homes-poor-quality-ratings-millions-ppp-loans-coronavirus-2020-8\">emergency funds</a>.&#160;</p><p>A <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/12/01/ppp-sba-data/\">Washington Post analysis</a> on Tuesday showed that more than half of the relief money went to just 5% of recipients. National food chains such as Uno Pizzeria &#38; Grill, Boston Market, and Cava Mezze Grill, as well as law firms and churches, were among the hundreds of larger businesses that received the maximum amount of $10 million allowed under the program, The Post reported.</p><p>Fifteen of the Trump Organization- and Kushner Cos.-owned properties reported that they kept either one employee or no employees, or did not report at all how many workers were kept on their payrolls, according to NBC News.</p><p>Two tenants at Trump Tower in New York received a PPP loan of over $100,000, NBC News reported. Still, they kept only three jobs. Similarly, four tenants at 666 5th Avenue, which is helmed by Kushner Cos., got more than $204,000 but held on to only half a dozen jobs, NBC News said.</p><p>The Triomphe Restaurant at the Trump International Hotel and Tower in New York City got a $2,164,543 loan, according to NBC News. The business didn't retain any workers and subsequently shut down.</p><p>Meanwhile, LB City Inc., a company at the Kushner family's New Jersey Bungalow Hotel, retained 155 jobs after acquiring a loan of over $505,500, NBC News reported.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\"The notion that Kushner Companies somehow improperly benefited from CARES Act Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loans is completely untrue and amounts to nothing more than politically motivated nonsense,\" Christopher Smith, the company's general counsel, told Insider in a statement on Wednesday afternoon.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">He added: \"Exactly two Kushner Companies' hotel operations affiliates received PPP loans. Every provision of the PPP program has been comprehensively abided with respect to each of the two loans — and every penny of the funds received from the program was utilized to fund employee payroll and benefits costs to maintain jobs imperiled by the COVID pandemic and associated lockdown measures.\"</p><p>The Trump Organization did not immediately respond to Insider's request for comment.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-organization-kushner-companies-3-million-ppp-loans-pandemic-report-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=oXW_sqKHY-M:ZMx9I_n8dGU:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=oXW_sqKHY-M:ZMx9I_n8dGU:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=oXW_sqKHY-M:ZMx9I_n8dGU:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=oXW_sqKHY-M:ZMx9I_n8dGU:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=oXW_sqKHY-M:ZMx9I_n8dGU:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=oXW_sqKHY-M:ZMx9I_n8dGU:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=oXW_sqKHY-M:ZMx9I_n8dGU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=oXW_sqKHY-M:ZMx9I_n8dGU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/oXW_sqKHY-M\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 02 Dec 2020 22:17:35 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fc7e983037cbd0018613673?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"6518b458a1e1d370777263aa8f53c82c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn24@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-49-795_38fc3b078cafd45e.webp","destWidth":4432,"destHeight":3324,"sourceBytes":1261968,"destBytes":1261968,"author":"oseddiq@insider.com (Oma Seddiq)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fc7e993037cbd0018613674?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn75@2020_6/2020/12/03/02-49-03-088_b802ca0dc8771d3f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=oXW_sqKHY-M:ZMx9I_n8dGU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn67@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-49-03-027_c86ce4d9c77eb2d8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=oXW_sqKHY-M:ZMx9I_n8dGU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn79@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-48-54-759_841ef7a0b65972aa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=oXW_sqKHY-M:ZMx9I_n8dGU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn36@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-50-763_5bf94dab4b4bed11.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/oXW_sqKHY-M":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn12@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-49-00-342_ca749d83604108a7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963709988},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","title":"The US will give Americans paper cards to remind them of their second COVID-19 vaccine dose, but will leave further messaging to states and pharmacies","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/americans-paper-reminders-second-covid-19-vaccine-dose-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fc7e062037cbd001861361e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Trump Gustave Perna Warp Speed\" height=\"1662\" width=\"2217\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Donald Trump and US Army Gen. Gustave F. Perna, during a news conference at the White House, September 18, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Army general Gustave Perna, who oversees the logistics of delivering COVID-19 vaccines to states, said the US will give Americans paper cards reminding them to come back for second doses.</li>\n<li>Vaccines from both Pfizer and Moderna, which are awaiting emergency authorized use from the FDA, require two doses.&#160;</li>\n<li>Experts previously told Business Insider getting 100% of Americans to show up for a second dose might be tricky.</li>\n<li>The US will begin transporting vaccines to states within 24-hours of an FDA greenlight, Perna said.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The US government will be giving Americans paper cards reminding them to get second doses of COVID-19 vaccines.</p><p>Army Gen. Gustave Perna, who oversees the logistics of delivering COVID-19 vaccines to states, said federal agents will send ancillary kits that include needles and syringes to doctor's offices and pharmacies that will distribute the vaccines. The kits also include paper cards to serve as reminders for patients to get second doses, he said at a Wednesday briefing. Americans will need to fill out the cards with the date they must go in a&#160;for a follow-up visit.</p><p>Perna said states, as well as pharmacies like CVS and Walgreens, will have their own plans to notify citizens of when to get second doses.</p><p>\"At the federal level, we have capability and capacity to send second dose messages out only if and when it's in collaboration with state laws, regulations, and policies,\" Perna said.</p><p>Pharmaceutical giant Pfizer and biotech firm Moderna have filed with&#160;the US Food and Drug Administration <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-vaccine-timeline-when-will-they-get-authorized-shots-start-2020-11\">for emergency authorized use</a> of their COVID-19 vaccines. An independent advisory committee will meet on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-fda-approve-pfizer-vaccine-biontech-covid-uk-mhra-2020-12\">December 10</a> and decide whether to recommend the FDA approve Pfizer's vaccine.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/insider-pfizer-biontech-historic-coronavirus-vaccine-program-2020-11?r=aa-sub\">How the pharma giant Pfizer teamed up with a little-known biotech to develop an effective coronavirus vaccine in record time</a></em></p><p>Both vaccines require two doses for optimal effectiveness. Pfizer's must be taken <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pfizer-coronavirus-vaccine-2-shots-2020-11\">three weeks</a> after the initial dose, and Moderna's <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/moderna-coronavirus-vaccine-requires-2-shots-month-apart-2020-11\">four weeks</a>.&#160;</p><p>Getting 100% of Americans to show up for a second dose might be tricky, experts told <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pfizer-coronavirus-vaccine-2-shots-2020-11\">Business Insider's Aylin Woodward</a>. Studies show a significant number of women <a href=\"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21440038/\">did not return to get second doses</a> of the human papillomavirus vaccine, which protects against cervical cancer.</p><p>A double-dose of the vaccines means states will need twice as many vials and syringes, which <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/covid-19-vaccine-experts-warn-glass-vials-planes-storage-shortage-2020-9\">might be in short supply</a>.&#160;</p><p>If taken correctly, early trial data indicates the vaccines will be highly effective at preventing individuals from getting COVID-19. A&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pfizer-says-coronavirus-vaccine-effective-will-submit-to-fda-eua-2020-11\">Pfizer</a>&#160;analysis of late-stage trial data found its shot is 95% effectiveness in preventing COVID-19, exceeding scientists' expectations. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/moderna-coronavirus-covid-vaccine-emergency-use-authorization-fda-2020-11\">Moderna</a> said its vaccine was 94.1% effective at protecting against COVID-19.</p><p>The US will begin transporting vaccines to states within 24-hours of an FDA greenlight, Perna said. Healthcare workers and long term care facility residents will receive the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/healthcare-workers-long-term-care-residents-recommended-to-get-vaccines-first-2020-12\">first doses</a> of the vaccine.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/americans-paper-reminders-second-covid-19-vaccine-dose-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=qUfhZZkP93Y:HnwfJaNkt_M:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qUfhZZkP93Y:HnwfJaNkt_M:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=qUfhZZkP93Y:HnwfJaNkt_M:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qUfhZZkP93Y:HnwfJaNkt_M:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=qUfhZZkP93Y:HnwfJaNkt_M:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=qUfhZZkP93Y:HnwfJaNkt_M:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qUfhZZkP93Y:HnwfJaNkt_M:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/qUfhZZkP93Y\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 02 Dec 2020 19:44:06 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fc7dffc037cbd001861361b?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"841b8e628d2039e0f283f4d39506cc2f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn19@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-48-49-688_0ad7a283933603c5.webp","destWidth":6390,"destHeight":4792,"sourceBytes":474200,"destBytes":474200,"author":"insider@insider.com (Allana Akhtar)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fc7e062037cbd001861361e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn80@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-49-00-913_26a355a1958e3b04.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qUfhZZkP93Y:HnwfJaNkt_M:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn96@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-48-56-084_0a1c3ba0e28a9dfa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qUfhZZkP93Y:HnwfJaNkt_M:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn47@2020_6/2020/12/03/02-48-52-315_58aa92bbb5c890b7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qUfhZZkP93Y:HnwfJaNkt_M:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn24@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-59-694_b6204f46b9042276.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/qUfhZZkP93Y":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn4@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-48-59-373_24febff093081e93.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963710038},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","title":"Bon Appétit is facing internet backlash and hundreds of one-star reviews for its version of the traditional Haitian dish soup joumou","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/bon-appetit-soup-joumou-backlash-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fc7e95950e71a00115587cb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"soup joumou\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A volunteer serves Joumou soup to guests during the 11th annual &#34;Haitian Community Thanksgiving Brunch&#34; at the Caribbean Market Place in 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Matias J. Ocner/Miami Herald/Tribune News Service/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The internet is after Bon App&#233;tit again for a recipe of soup joumou, a traditional Haitian dish, that many say is inaccurate.</li>\n<li>The food magazine updated its recipe after hundreds of one-star reviews, along with critiques on Twitter and Instagram. The byline was also adjusted after Yewande Komolafe, who was listed as one of its authors, said she had nothing to do with the recipe.</li>\n<li>The Cond&#233; Nast publication had a public reckoning this summer as former and current staffers of color alleged the publication failed to include diverse content, among other problems.</li>\n<li>\"We deeply regret offending people and misrepresenting this dish, which is an important part of global food history,\" a representative for Bon App&#233;tit told Business Insider. \"We are sorry for under-emphasizing that this dish is loosely inspired by soup joumou.\"</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>On Tuesday, Bon Appétit posted a recipe for soup joumou, an essential dish in Haitian cuisine. But the glossy food publication's version drew criticism from readers, who said it wasn't at all close to what the famous dish is supposed to be.</p><p>The <a href=\"https://www.bonappetit.com/recipe/pumpkin-soup-with-spiced-nuts\">Bon Appétit recipe includes</a> candied nuts with maple syrup, coconut milk, chile-nutmeg oil, and other ingredients not typically found in the dish — and some not even native to Haiti.</p><p>The Condé Nast food brand saw a public reckoning this year <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bon-appetit-adam-rapoport-toxic-racism-culture-2020-6\">over how it treats employees of color</a>, and leadership <a href=\"https://www.marketplace.org/2020/12/02/bon-appetit-new-editor-in-chief-dawn-davis-brand-adviser-marcus-samuelsson-the-rise/\">has publicly spoken about a renewed focus of increasing diversity</a> within its magazine and video content. But this attempt was slammed almost immediately.</p><p>In the day after the recipe's posting, nearly 400 readers left one-star reviews on the page, and many criticized it on Twitter and Instagram.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Cedu  (@Sedorikkuu) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1333805775521796098?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">December 1, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>Following the backlash, Bon Appétit renamed the recipe, which now reads \"Pumpkin Soup With Spiced Nuts.\" It also appended the following editor's note:</p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\">We've updated the name and byline of this dish, and changed the headnote to match the excerpted recipe, which is chef Marcus Samuelsson's take on Haitian soup joumou, from Samuelsson's cookbook 'The Rise.' We apologize for misrepresenting this recipe.</p><p>\"We deeply regret offending people and misrepresenting this dish, which is an important part of global food history. We are sorry for under-emphasizing that this dish is loosely inspired by soup joumou,\" a representative for Bon Appétit told Business Insider.</p><p>\"The soup recipe on Bon Appétit was initially adapted from my book, The Rise,\" Samuelsson told Business Insider in a statement. \"The headnote has been updated to reflect how it is described in full in my book, where it is included as an homage to the Haitian Independence Soup, soup joumou. I apologize for how it was presented in the issue of Bon Appétit that I guest edited. This error is not at all in line with how we approached sharing or celebrating Black culinary traditions in The Rise or in Bon Appétit and I apologize to those we have offended.\"</p><h2>'My grandmother ... is rolling in her grave'</h2><p>For Princess Mettelus, who was born in Haiti and now lives in Bradenton, Florida, the recipe felt like \"a slap in the face.\"</p><p>\"It's like, our culture isn't good enough for for what it is,\" she told Business Insider. \"Yours didn't taste well, so we just completely changed it.\"</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;roxane gay  (@rgay) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1334183141683175427?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">December 2, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>The take on joumou was especially insulting, Mettelus said, given the soup's history. Under French colonial rule, which lasted nearly 200 years, enslaved Africans in Haiti made pumpkin soup while working on forced labor camps. The French denied them the right to eat the soup, instead forcing them to eat what Mettelus described as a bread soup with leftover broth.</p><p>Once Haiti declared independence on January 1, 1804, soup joumou — similar to what the French demanded to eat — became the traditional dish to celebrate freedom in Haiti.&#160;</p><p>\"Negative 5 stars for disturbing my grandmother who is rolling in her grave and missing the mark and understanding how history, family and food go hand in hand,\" one commenter named Mike V. wrote. \"Disrespectful to the Nth degree!\"</p><h2>The recipe's byline also drew controversy&#160;</h2><p>The soup joumou recipe was adapted from \"The Rise: Black Cooks and the Soul of American Food,\" published in October by chef Marcus Samuelsson. Samuelsson, who was born in Ethiopia and grew up in Sweden, is also a brand advisor for Bon Appétit.&#160;</p><p>The original recipe had two other names listed under the byline: recipe developer Yewande Komolafe and chef Tamie Cook. Cook and Komolafe developed recipes for Samuelsson's cookbook.</p><p>Both were removed this morning after Komolafe, the author of an upcoming cookbook of Nigerian recipes, said on Instagram that she had nothing to do with the recipe. Komolafe and Cook did not immediately respond to Business Insider's requests for comment.</p><blockquote class=\"instagram-media\"   style=\"background:#FFF; border:0; border-radius:3px; box-shadow:0 0 1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.5),0 1px 10px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 1px; max-width:540; padding:0; width:99.375%; width:-webkit-calc(100% - 2px); width:calc(100% - 2px); data.width~540;\">\n\t<div style=\"padding:8px;\">\n\t\t<div style=\"background:#F8F8F8; line-height:0; margin-top:40px; padding:62.4537037037% 0; text-align:center; width:100%;\">\n\t\t\t<div style=\"background:url(data:image/png;base64,); display:block; height:44px; margin:0 auto -44px; position:relative; top:-22px; width:44px;\"></div>\n\t\t</div>\n\t\t<p style=\"margin:8px 0 0 0; padding:0 4px;\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/CITHuZwDoOZ\" style=\" color:#000; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; font-style:normal; font-weight:normal; line-height:17px; text-decoration:none; word-wrap:break-word;\" target=\"_blank\"></a></p> <p style=\" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px; margin-bottom:0; margin-top:8px; overflow:hidden; padding:8px 0 7px; text-align:center; text-overflow:ellipsis; white-space:nowrap;\">A post shared by Yewande (@yewande_komolafe)<time style=\" font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px;\" datetime=\"\"></time>\n\t\t</p></div></blockquote><script async defer src=\"//platform.instagram.com/en_US/embeds.js\"></script><p>&#160;</p><h2>Bon Appétit has had a year of missteps</h2><p>Former and current employees of Bon Appétit told Business Insider in June that leadership at the food brand refused their staffers' efforts to feature diverse recipes and cooks.</p><p>Ryan Walker-Hartshorn, who was previously the assistant to the editor-in-chief and then the only Black woman on staff, said she regularly hosted pitch meetings to include content from outside the white American lens. \"They would still come with the same pitches about Martha's Vineyard and lobster rolls,\" Walker-Hartshorn told Business Insider at the time.&#160;</p><p>\"White food is considered the most accessible and 'simple,'\" then-contributor Priya Krishna <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bon-appetit-adam-rapoport-toxic-racism-culture-2020-6\">said&#160;in a June email interview with Business Insider</a>. \"Especially early on, whenever I pitched a home cooking recipe story featuring non-white food, I felt like I had to work twice as hard to prove that it deserved a place in the magazine.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/bon-appetit-soup-joumou-backlash-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=ZxcGBBNBk4A:zS4WOD2bAwM:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=ZxcGBBNBk4A:zS4WOD2bAwM:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZxcGBBNBk4A:zS4WOD2bAwM:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=ZxcGBBNBk4A:zS4WOD2bAwM:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZxcGBBNBk4A:zS4WOD2bAwM:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=ZxcGBBNBk4A:zS4WOD2bAwM:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZxcGBBNBk4A:zS4WOD2bAwM:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ZxcGBBNBk4A\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 02 Dec 2020 19:35:33 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5ee03f454dca68289e715753?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"3c290b943025320b23e9b208ba304186","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn88@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-55-752_e6e835017071edc2.webp","destWidth":2671,"destHeight":2003,"sourceBytes":127988,"destBytes":127988,"author":"rpremack@businessinsider.com (Rachel Premack)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fc7e95950e71a00115587cb?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn51@2020_6/2020/12/03/02-48-50-853_40c8e93a2aabb296.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZxcGBBNBk4A:zS4WOD2bAwM:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn76@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-49-02-337_2a2808c2915e6307.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZxcGBBNBk4A:zS4WOD2bAwM:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn60@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-52-488_b80c7c6ff1041acc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZxcGBBNBk4A:zS4WOD2bAwM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn12@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-58-633_e2380b68ea8b2755.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ZxcGBBNBk4A":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn32@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-55-377_ffe284525839ecef.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963710018},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","title":"WATCH: Meet the last family practicing this 400-year-old Indian art form","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/rogan-art-india-khatri-family-2020-12","description":"<div style=\"position:relative; overflow:hidden; padding-bottom:56.25%\">\n<iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/wnZFzqy6-jZbcmOYf.html\"\nwidth=\"100%\" height=\"100%\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"auto\" title=\"WATCH: Meet the last family practicing this 400-year-old Indian art form\"\nstyle=\"position:absolute;\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n</div><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Rogan is an ancient Indian art form that has been practiced for 400 years.</li>\n<li>The Khatri family has practiced Rogan art for eight generations, and they believe they're the last ones keeping the tradition alive in India.</li>\n<li>The rise of industrial textiles in the 1980s put many artisans out of work. And the COVID-19 pandemic has threatened the business as tourism has dried up.</li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/BusinessInsiderToday/\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\">View more episodes of Business Insider Today on Facebook.</a></strong></li>\n</ul><p>The palm of the hand is the essential tool for getting the ancient painting technique of Rogan just right.&#160;</p><p>Rogan art is believed to have come to India from Persia around 400 years ago. The designs were once common on<a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/08/arts/08iht-sckutch08.html\"> ceremonial clothing and bed covers throughout India</a>.&#160;</p><p>Today, the Khatri family says they are the only artisans left in the world practicing this traditional craft.</p><p>The base of the paint is castor oil, and it's what gives the art its name — Rogan means oil in Farsi.&#160;The oil is heated over a fire for two days until it becomes a honey-like texture. Then, it's combined with crushed pigment to create the paint.&#160;</p><p>The painting process involves just two tools: a metal stylus and a hand. Abdul Gaffur Khatri, the eldest of the family business, swirls the paint in his hand to create heat and thin it out. He then floats the threat of paint over the fabric using the metal stylus.&#160;</p><p>While he has an idea of the final design in his mind, the painting process is completely freehand.&#160;&#160;</p><p>\"The perfect thread out of this color, which can run on cloth, is in the mind of the artist,\" Khatri told Business Insider. \"It is all God's gift. It cannot be done by everyone or by any machine.\"</p><p>Khatri can finish some pieces in five days, while more complex designs can take him up to two years. Larger wall art pieces can cost over $1,000.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fc8115f037cbd0018613788?format=jpeg\" alt=\"BIT_Rogan_Art_Youtube_CMS_Yahoo_FB_V1.00_00_28_08.Still006\" height=\"1080\" width=\"1920\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A metal stylus and one&#39;s hand are the only things needed to create Rogan art.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Prakhar Jain for Business Insider Today</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The Khatri family normally sell their pieces to tourists in the town of Bhuj, about 25 miles from the small village of Nirona, where they work. This year, the pandemic put a strain on their peak season.&#160;</p><p>\"I can tell you that we have incurred losses because tourists didn't come, and this business depends on them. There's no other source. So what do we do?\" Khatri told Business Insider, \"Now we are just waiting and watching to see what will happen next.\"</p><p>The struggle feels familiar — the rise of mass produced textiles in the 1980s forced many artisans to drop their crafts and look for more lucrative work. Khatri made the hard decision to leave the family business and search for opportunities in Mumbai.&#160;</p><p>\"In 1980 I decided that I will not waste my life on this art,\" Khatri told Business Insider, \"And there were some arguments in the family due to that because at that time sending a kid from a village to Mumbai was a big deal.\"</p><p>Khatri returned to his village just a few years later after his family plead with him to carry on the tradition.&#160;</p><p>\"I remember at that time I promised him that I'll dedicate my whole life to this art,\" Khatri told Business Insider. \"And now I can say that promise is complete.\"</p><p>Since then, the Khatri family has brought rogan art to the international level. They've earned over 10 awards for their work, and India's Prime Minister even gifted one of their pieces to President Barack Obama in 2014.</p><p>Now, the family uses social media and education to spread awareness about this rare art form. Since starting a program in 2010 to grow and diversify the village's Rogan artists, they've trained around 300 women, 20 of whom went on to work for the family.&#160;</p><p>Though they've since had to lay off those employees due to the pandemic, they plan to hire them back when business returns to normal.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/rogan-art-india-khatri-family-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=L-Tm6U1ChaE:Xgn24iI6CpQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L-Tm6U1ChaE:Xgn24iI6CpQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=L-Tm6U1ChaE:Xgn24iI6CpQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L-Tm6U1ChaE:Xgn24iI6CpQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=L-Tm6U1ChaE:Xgn24iI6CpQ:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=L-Tm6U1ChaE:Xgn24iI6CpQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L-Tm6U1ChaE:Xgn24iI6CpQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/L-Tm6U1ChaE\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 02 Dec 2020 23:08:42 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fc8116850e71a00115588dc?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"9126cef003dffe7a87405e0ac1de6f44","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn16@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-48-680_ad6421d15453f450.webp","destWidth":1440,"destHeight":1080,"sourceBytes":61402,"destBytes":61402,"author":"insider@insider.com (Dylan Barth)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fc8115f037cbd0018613788?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn20@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-49-02-740_58c2955cee761e3f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L-Tm6U1ChaE:Xgn24iI6CpQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn4@2020_6/2020/12/03/02-49-03-284_ac5b3d4cd3128d04.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L-Tm6U1ChaE:Xgn24iI6CpQ:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn19@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-48-57-843_7e77d19954cb5f0e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L-Tm6U1ChaE:Xgn24iI6CpQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn88@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-01-213_96415f964dcb5d90.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/L-Tm6U1ChaE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn27@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-51-307_8d41e6003b099c66.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963710012},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","title":"How to create and customize folders on an iPhone to organize your apps","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-create-a-folder-on-iphone","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5cddaf5c021b4c066b6b7553?format=jpeg\" alt=\"looking at phone iphone apple \" height=\"924\" width=\"1232\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Creating folders on your iPhone is a great way to organize apps on your home screen.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jeff Chiu/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>To create a folder on your iPhone, all you need to do is drag an app onto another app.&#160;</li>\n<li>Folders are easy to edit and they can contain more than one page, so you have plenty of space for your apps.</li>\n<li><strong>Creating folders can declutter your home screen and help keep related apps organized.</strong></li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"4c86c1c3a45644bf07d168dc4c802e5e\"><strong>Visit Business Insider's Tech Reference library for more stories</strong></a><strong>.</strong></li>\n</ul><p>If you're like most people, chances are your <a href=\"http://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?subId1=bi_051619_create-a-folder-on-iphone&u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fiphone%2Fiphone-xs-shop-by-carrier%2Fpcmcat1536788648291.c%3Fid%3Dpcmcat15367886482918291\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">iPhone</a> is full of dozens of apps, many of which you use daily and others that only come in handy on rare occasions (but that you're not willing to delete).</p><p>An abundance of downloaded apps can mean scrolling through multiple screens to find the one you want, and if you're someone who prefers a bit more organization, this can be a nightmare.</p><p>Thankfully, you can easily organize your <a href=\"http://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?subId1=bi_051619_create-a-folder-on-iphone&u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fiphone%2Fiphone-xs-shop-by-carrier%2Fpcmcat1536788648291.c%3Fid%3Dpcmcat15367886482918291\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">iPhone</a> apps into folders. Creating folders is a simple process that can be completed in just a few seconds. You can also name your folders to make keeping your apps in order that much easier.</p><p>Here's what you need to know.</p><h2><strong>How to create a new folder on your iPhone</strong></h2><p><strong>1. </strong>To create a folder, press and hold the icon of the first app you would like to move into a folder until all of your application icons begin to shake and a small X appears in the upper left-hand side of each.</p><p><strong>2. </strong>Press down on the app icon again and drag it across your screen to another app you would like to place in the same folder. Hovering one app icon over another will create a folder; stop holding down the application icon to drop both applications into your new folder.</p><p><strong>3. </strong>Note that the folder will be automatically titled by iPhone based on the applications contained within in it. For instance, placing two banking apps within a folder will result in the folder being titled \"Finance.\"</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5cdd8781021b4c03f8646c75?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_6659.PNG\" height=\"1280\" width=\"720\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Your iPhone will automatically assign a name based on what sort of apps you use to create the folder.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jennifer Still/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>How to change the name of your iPhone folder</strong></h2><p>You can change the name of your iPhone folders in much the same way you created them.</p><p><strong>1. </strong>To begin, press and hold one of the app icons from inside the folder you want to change the name of until the apps within it begin to shake and a small X appears in the upper left-hand side of each.</p><p><strong>2. </strong>When this happens, the title box of the folder will become editable. Tap within it, then type the name you would like the folder to have. It's that easy!</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5cdd8747021b4c03f8646c73?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_6660.PNG\" height=\"1280\" width=\"720\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You can give your folders any name that you&#39;d like.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jennifer Still/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>How to delete an iPhone folder</strong></h2><p>There may come a time when you wish to delete a folder you've created, and have your apps listed individually on your home screen. When that happens, it's easy to delete the folder and restore the apps to their original locations.</p><p><strong>1. </strong>To delete an iPhone folder, simply press and hold the icon of an app within that folder until all apps begin to shake and a small X appears in the upper left-hand corner.</p><p><strong>2. </strong>Press and drag apps one at a time from within the folder to your home screen. Once the folder is empty, it will automatically be deleted.</p><h2><strong>Related coverage from&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"4c86c1c3a45644bf07d168dc4c802e5e\">Tech Reference</a>:</strong></h2><ul><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-change-apple-id-on-iphone\">How to change your Apple ID on an iPhone</a></h3></li><li><h3><a 10:48:30","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","title":"Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer just embraced a $908 billion coronavirus relief plan in a huge concession to get federal aid out the door quickly","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/democrats-just-embraced-a-908-billion-coronavirus-stimulus-plan-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fc66625037cbd0018613198?format=jpeg\" alt=\"pelosi mcconnell stimulus checks\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell.\n<p class=\"copyright\">BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/POOL/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Congressional Democrats came out in favor of a bipartisan $908 billion spending plan on Wednesday.</li>\n<li>It's a large concession for Democrats, who held out for a multitrillion-dollar rescue package for several months.</li>\n<li>Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the plan's framework \"should be used as the basis for immediate bipartisan, bicameral negotiations.\"</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Congressional Democratic leaders came out in favor of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bipartisan-group-of-senators-unveils-stimulus-plan-2020-12\">a $908 billion stimulus package</a> on Wednesday, saying it should be the starting point in negotiations with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell.</p><p>Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said in a statement that the plan's framework \"should be used as the basis for immediate bipartisan, bicameral negotiations.\"</p><p>Their backing of the bipartisan legislation represents a huge concession after Democrats pushed a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-checks-coronavirus-details-house-democrats-pelosi-mnuchin-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">multitrillion-dollar spending plan</a> for over six months to confront the economic and health crises. The overall spending in the latest rescue package, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-908-billion-munchin-romney-collins-2020-12\">introduced on Tuesday</a>, is less than a third of the $3.4 trillion plan they sought in May.</p><p>Sen. John Thune, a member of GOP Senate leadership, told reporters on Capitol Hill that the announcement from Pelosi and Schumer was \"progress.\"</p><p>\"It's a move in the right direction, and I think hopefully it'll be helpful in us getting a deal done,\" he said. \"They had this huge request, which was unreasonable. They've gotten reasonable, and I think that could help us get to a solution.\"</p><p>Congress has increasingly faced pressure to act as coronavirus cases rise nationwide and several emergency rescue programs to aid unemployed people are set to expire in just over three weeks.</p><p>President-elect Joe Biden has also recently <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-democratic-stimulus-plan-congress-republicans-negotiations-2020-11\">urged lawmakers</a> to pass another aid package before they adjourn on December 11.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-908-billion-munchin-romney-collins-2020-12\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"7726b1e9a60ba2187bf80f59e4d93e25\">Lawmakers just unveiled a $908 billion coronavirus stimulus deal that would boost unemployment payments and help small businesses. Here's what's in the package</a></em></p><p>The measures in the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-908-billion-munchin-romney-collins-2020-12\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">short-term plan introduced on Tuesday</a> include:</p><ul><li>$300 federal weekly unemployment benefits retroactive from December 1 until at least March</li><li>$240 billion in new Paycheck Protection Program assistance for small businesses</li><li>$160 billion in funding for state and local governments</li><li>$51 billion in new healthcare and vaccine-related funds</li><li>A temporary liability shield for businesses from coronavirus-related lawsuits</li></ul><p>The plan was introduced by Democratic Sens. Joe Manchin of West Virginia and Mark Warner of Virginia; Republican Sens. Susan Collins of Maine, Mitt Romney of Utah, and Bill Cassidy of Louisiana; and independent Sen. Angus King of Maine.</p><p>The proposal was sparse on details other than overall spending levels, though lawmakers <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-908-billion-munchin-romney-collins-2020-12\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">took questions from reporters</a> about the deal on Tuesday. Manchin, one of its key negotiators, told reporters on Wednesday that the formal text of the interim rescue package was expected to be ready as early as Monday.</p><p>\"I don't think there's anything else out there that can give us the relief the country needs,\" Manchin said.</p><p>The plan left out a second round of $1,200 direct payments for taxpayers, likely in an effort to keep its price tag below $1 trillion. Many GOP senators have been reluctant to support an expensive plan, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/deficit-stimulus-republicans-biden-senate-budget-2020-10\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">citing the rising budget deficit</a>. A round of checks like the ones distributed earlier this year would cost about $300 billion.</p><p>The plan didn't address a range of federal programs set to expire this month, including the Pandemic Unemployment Assistance program for gig workers and a moratorium on evictions. Nearly <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/millions-could-lose-unemployment-aid-by-december-without-coronavirus-stimulus-2020-11\">12 million Americans</a> are at risk of losing their jobless aid this month.</p><p>McConnell dismissed the plan on Tuesday and pressed for <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-coronavirus-senate-mcconnell-500-billion-vote-2020-10\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">lower spending</a> similar to a relief measure unveiled twice, in September and October.</p><p>The Kentucky Republican <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/senate-republicans-stimulus-plan-extra-federal-unemployment-benefits-2020-12\">circulated a new version</a> of the $500 billion package among Republicans on Wednesday. It didn't include any additional funding for federal unemployment benefits, and it would extend aid programs for gig workers and state benefits for a month beyond December 31. The <a href=\"https://twitter.com/DonFSchneider/status/1334178894338023430?s=20\">bulk of the funding</a> would be directed to small businesses, then to schools.</p><p>Many economists and Federal Reserve officials have urged Congress to pass a new relief bill. Unemployment claims have increased for the past two weeks, and the recent surges in coronavirus cases have caused states to renew business restrictions.</p><p>At a virtual event on the state of the economy on Wednesday, Biden appeared to express support for the compromise package. He said it \"wouldn't be the answer, but it would be immediate help for a lot of things quickly.\"</p><p>He indicated his transition team was already drafting more legislative proposals to address the economic downturn as well. He said that the relief plan \"at best, is only going to be a down payment for what's going to happen early next year.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/democrats-just-embraced-a-908-billion-coronavirus-stimulus-plan-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a
