src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/fxqt0YHxvaQ\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />\n   </hr>\n  </hr>\n </hr>\n</hr>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 02 Dec 2020 21:55:29 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f5a8466e6ff30001d4e8291?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"5e53dbfc6ad17022de320d1ef010d69c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn20@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-39-911_bfbfeeaf5e6b4358.webp","destWidth":2258,"destHeight":1693,"sourceBytes":934200,"destBytes":934200,"author":"ljohnson@businessinsider.com (Lauren Johnson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f5a8466e6ff30001d4e8291?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn20@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-39-911_bfbfeeaf5e6b4358.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fc803bc037cbd0018613746?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn16@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-54-172_1032002b1004030e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fc80bb4037cbd001861376a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn59@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-48-48-726_280a82542668cb18.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fxqt0YHxvaQ:L8QYNu8kZG4:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn4@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-48-52-176_7998f17e7fb9166b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fxqt0YHxvaQ:L8QYNu8kZG4:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn75@2020_6/2020/12/03/02-48-50-952_7e77d94b923f6326.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fxqt0YHxvaQ:L8QYNu8kZG4:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn55@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-49-01-518_89b601e576c5e458.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/fxqt0YHxvaQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn61@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-801_58abc636589f9e83.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963710043},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","title":"Video from China's rock-collecting spacecraft shows the probe stick its landing on the moon","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/watch-china-change-5-spacecraft-land-on-moon-surface-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fc7e2a7037cbd0018613634?format=jpeg\" alt=\"chang&#39;e 5 pano\" height=\"2146\" width=\"4050\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A panoramic image taken by Chang&#39;e 5 after it successfully landed. Mons Rümker is visible in the distance.\n<p class=\"copyright\">CNSA</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>China landed a spacecraft on the moon Tuesday as part of its rock-collecting mission, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/china-launches-moon-mission-to-collect-rocks-2020-11\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"610d9193af989b53fdfb4b911e56b680\">Chang'e-5</a>.</li>\n<li>The probe is set to drill rock&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/china-mars-spacecraft-launch-2020-rover-sample-return-2019-1\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"36a44008beecbaf3fdf55aedf8d626f0\">samples</a> and send them back to Earth by mid-December.</li>\n<li>If successful, it will be the first time a country has brought home moon rocks in more than 40 years.</li>\n<li>China's space agency released video of the landing on Wednesday.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>China <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/china-landed-change-spacecraft-moon-rock-lunar-samples-2020-12\">landed a rock-collecting spacecraft on the moon</a> on Tuesday, the latest in a series of ambitious lunar missions.</p><p>The lander is one of four robots in a mission called Chang'e-5, which aims to send a sample of the lunar surface to Earth before the end of 2020. If successful, it will be the first time a country has brought home moon rock in more than 40 years.</p><p>The China National Space Administration (CNSA) abruptly cut off its live coverage about a half hour before its scheduled landing at 10:13 a.m. ET on Tuesday. But the agency later announced that the spacecraft had touched down at 10:11 a.m. ET.</p><p>On Wednesday, a state-run media organization, China Xinhua News, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/XHNews/status/1334140412429094912\">released sped-up footage</a> of the probe executing a gentle landing on the pockmarked lunar surface.</p><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><div style='position:relative; padding-bottom:calc(56.67% + 44px)'><iframe src='https://gfycat.com/ifr/ScrawnyOffbeatDolphin' frameborder='0' scrolling='no' width='100%' height='100%' style='position:absolute;top:0;left:0;' allowfullscreen></iframe></div></div><p>As it descended, the probe took pictures of its landing site and sent them to computers on Earth, so engineers could help it maneuver around any large rocks or other hazards on the surface. Its engine cut off several meters above the surface, allowing it to make a slow, gentle landing.</p><h2>The first time collecting moon rocks since 1976</h2><p>The lander's robotic arm is programmed to drill about 6 feet into the lunar surface to collect 4.4 pounds of lunar rock and dust from a previously unexplored region: a volcanic plain called Mons Rümker. The material could provide new information about the moon's past volcanic activity.</p><p>The robotic arm should then transfer the sample to an ascent module sitting on top of the lander. With the sample secure, that module should lift off to rendezvous with the mission's orbiter, which is currently circling the moon with its Earth-reentry module in tow. If all goes well, the trio of robots will then return to Earth with their moon rock prize, which is set to&#160;land in Inner Mongolia in mid-December.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fc7e30b50e71a001155878b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"chang&#39;e 5 image\" height=\"2843\" width=\"4265\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A rendering of the Chang&#39;e 5 landing probe on the lunar surface.\n<p class=\"copyright\">CNSA</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>\"This is a really audacious mission,\" David Draper, the deputy chief scientist at NASA,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/23/science/china-moon-rocks.html\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"86d356a70ffbdf8b1d61bd34ca4c36f8\">told the New York Times</a>. \"They're going to move the ball down the field in a big way with respect to understanding a lot of things that are important about lunar history.\"</p><p>For one, the samples could show that the moon displayed volcanic activity as recently as 1.2 billion years ago – a discovery that could \"rewrite the history of the moon,\" Xiao Long, a planetary geologist at the China University of Geosciences in Wuhan,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-03064-z\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"5977c39262550467f40d1d54ebf9a726\">told Nature in November</a>.</p><p>So far, scientists have only been able to study moon rock samples from lunar regions that are at least 3 billion years old, so their knowledge of the moon's volcanic activity ends around then.&#160;</p><p>The last time any country collected lunar rocks <a href=\"https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2020/11/china-set-bring-back-first-rocks-moon-more-40-years\">was in 1976</a>, when the Soviet Union's last Luna mission returned to Earth.&#160;</p><h2>NASA and China are racing to land humans on the moon</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9474614743a3001216b7b2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"moon astronauts artemis\" height=\"2160\" width=\"3840\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An artist’s illustration depicts Artemis astronauts on the moon.\n<p class=\"copyright\">NASA via AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The Chang'e-5 mission launched early on November 24, local time, from China's Wenchang Satellite Launch Center on Hainan Island.</p><p>It's the sixth in a series of ambitious missions by China to explore the moon, which could potentially lead to the building of a human settlement there.</p><p>This is the third time that CNSA has landed a robot on the lunar surface. The agency now has seven spacecraft operating on the moon or in its orbit, according to SpaceNews correspondent&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/AJ_FI/status/1333373963343376384\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"442c5a85fd857c570c764ba5d6b75ef2\">Andrew Jones</a>.&#160;</p><p>NASA has similar ambitions to establish a permanent lunar base, but it has not yet launched the precursor moon missions needed to reach that goal. The agency hasn't landed anything on the moon since 1972.</p><p>However, NASA and Elon Musk's space-exploration company SpaceX successfully sent&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/spacex-launches-rocket-mission-nasa-astronauts-crew-1-dragon-spaceship-2020-11\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"8010c95d23d478c687ff0b8254717550\">two astronaut crews</a>&#160;to the&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/astronauts-attach-spacex-crew-dragon-spaceship-international-space-station-2020-11\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"4198356a556fc6df990cb88aad71d6d0\">International Space Station</a>&#160;this year, marking the first time the US has launched astronauts since 2011. The missions have paved the way for landing humans on the moon again, which NASA aims to do in 2024.</p><p>The agency also plans to send its first rover to the moon's south pole to map out ice reserves in 2023.</p><p><em>Dave Mosher contributed reporting.&#160;</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/watch-china-change-5-spacecraft-land-on-moon-surface-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=OfNYVlyLles:v1Wt2cfM9MU:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=OfNYVlyLles:v1Wt2cfM9MU:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OfNYVlyLles:v1Wt2cfM9MU:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=OfNYVlyLles:v1Wt2cfM9MU:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OfNYVlyLles:v1Wt2cfM9MU:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=OfNYVlyLles:v1Wt2cfM9MU:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=OfNYVlyLles:v1Wt2cfM9MU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OfNYVlyLles:v1Wt2cfM9MU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/OfNYVlyLles\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 02 Dec 2020 19:41:47 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fc7e34750e71a001155878e?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"d014d5a48da6d302a48fd1af3394b869","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn44@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-48-49-748_2c3c61e2eb6329b4.webp","destWidth":3117,"destHeight":2338,"sourceBytes":136890,"destBytes":136890,"author":"insider@insider.com (Susie Neilson,Morgan McFall-Johnsen)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fc7e2a7037cbd0018613634?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn92@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-49-187_1010999f03c454c5.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fc7e30b50e71a001155878b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn64@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-59-029_21412cf9f3d09bf8.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9474614743a3001216b7b2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn43@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-467_ae59d6623902221a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OfNYVlyLles:v1Wt2cfM9MU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn44@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-52-304_22b9a463bf7fa1ce.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OfNYVlyLles:v1Wt2cfM9MU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn80@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-53-762_05d7c3f67576edfe.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OfNYVlyLles:v1Wt2cfM9MU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn28@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-49-02-975_a9cadb1dcc36aa24.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/OfNYVlyLles":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn31@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-58-053_6e86b5fed998be00.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963710019},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","title":"Colombian drug smugglers are outsourcing their 'narco subs'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/colombian-drug-smugglers-outsourcing-narco-subs-to-get-cocaine-north-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5522ad14eab8ea85712860cb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"narco sub\" height=\"1100\" width=\"2200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A fiberglass submarine used to smuggle cocaine is seen in Buenaventura, Colombia, June 24, 2008.\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Jaime Saldarriaga</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Colombian and US authorities have apprehended organizations dedicated to building \"narco subs\" for drug-trafficking groups.</li>\n<li>Outsourcing the construction and, in some cases, operation of the vessels saves those traffickers from having to deal with the logistics required to smuggle drugs overseas.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>In November, the Attorney General's Office, the Colombian Navy and the US Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) <a href=\"https://www.fiscalia.gov.co/colombia/narcotrafico/caen-11-extraditables-que-harian-parte-de-una-estructura-criminal-senalada-de-enviar-toneladas-de-cocaina-en-semisumergibles-electricos/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">arrested</a> 11 alleged members of an organization specialized in the manufacturing of submarines and adapting other vessels for the purpose of cocaine trafficking.</p><p>The network <a href=\"https://caracol.com.co/emisora/2020/11/05/cali/1604609264_602277.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">operated</a> in the departments of Cauca, Valle del Cauca, Nariño and Chocó, where the arrested members obtained building materials, built the vessels, and coordinated logistics with different groups to move the drugs abroad, mostly to Mexico.</p><p>According to a <a href=\"https://www.armada.mil.co/es/content/capturados-once-presuntos-integrantes-una-organizacion-narcotraficante\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">press release</a> by the Colombian Navy, the network maintained an agreement with the National Liberation Army (Ejército de Liberación Nacional — <a href=\"https://www.insightcrime.org/colombia-organized-crime-news/eln-profile/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ELN</a>), under which the criminal group provided security in rural areas along the Cucurrupí river in northern Colombia, where the network built submarines.</p><p>However, a statement by Colombia's army also <a href=\"https://www.cgfm.mil.co/es/blog/capturados-11-integrantes-de-una-organizacion-narcotraficante\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">indicated</a> that the submarine builders had achieved enough fame that they had also been contacted by criminal groups in Mexico and Guatemala to build vessels for them.</p><h2>InSight Crime analysis</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d277e4b2516e91f8f121fd4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Coast Guard narco sub\" height=\"1000\" width=\"1400\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>US Coast Guard crew members inspect a self-propelled semi-submersible in the Eastern Pacific Ocean, June 19, 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">US Coast Guard photo</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>With cocaine production and export having boomed in recent years, as well as during the pandemic, it makes sense for criminal groups to outsource specific parts of the drug trafficking chain such as the construction of submarines.</p><p>This method reduces the expenses assumed by drug trafficking groups, preventing them from having to handle all the logistics involved with shipping cocaine internationally.</p><p>Adm. Hernando Mattos, commander of the Navy's anti-narcotics Poseidon Task Force, told the newspaper<a href=\"https://www.eltiempo.com/justicia/conflicto-y-narcotrafico/autoridades-han-incautado-27-semisumergibles-con-coca-en-lo-que-va-de-2020-534998\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> El Tiempo</a> that \"it is not uncommon to find that drugs from two or three networks are transported in one … submarine so that they can jointly cover the shipping and costs of these vessels, which can reach up to $1 million.\"</p><p>This is not the first such network to emerge. In August 2018, Colombian police <a href=\"https://www.elpais.com.co/judicial/cae-red-que-fabricaba-semisumergibles-para-enviar-cocaina-al-exterior-desde-el-pacifico.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">dismantled</a> a ring dedicated to manufacturing semi-submersibles for trafficking cocaine from Colombia's Pacific Coast to Central America and the United States. This ring had allegedly even had contacts with Mexico's Sinaloa Cartel.</p><p>The use of submarines is now a mainstay for Colombian organized crime groups. In 2019, 23 such vessels were <a href=\"https://caracol.com.co/emisora/2019/10/11/cali/1570826323_319477.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">confiscated.</a> And between January and August 2020, 27 were <a href=\"https://www.eltiempo.com/justicia/conflicto-y-narcotrafico/autoridades-han-incautado-27-semisumergibles-con-coca-en-lo-que-va-de-2020-534998\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">seized</a> between the Colombian coast and international waters.</p><p>Many get through unnoticed. A 2018<a href=\"https://www.univision.com/local/los-angeles-kmex/por-que-eeuu-va-perdiendo-la-batalla-contra-los-narcosubmarinos-que-cruzan-el-pacifico-cargados-de-cocaina\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> report</a> by Univision indicated that the US Coast Guard only seizes a quarter of drugs transported by submarines as these cannot be detected by radar. According to the report, the vessels are covered by a layer of lead and exhaust fumes are cooled down before being released which helps to avoid detection by infrared sensors on patrolling ships.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/colombian-drug-smugglers-outsourcing-narco-subs-to-get-cocaine-north-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=0-HxqoyJzkA:F5j7VQgg2po:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=0-HxqoyJzkA:F5j7VQgg2po:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0-HxqoyJzkA:F5j7VQgg2po:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=0-HxqoyJzkA:F5j7VQgg2po:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0-HxqoyJzkA:F5j7VQgg2po:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=0-HxqoyJzkA:F5j7VQgg2po:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=0-HxqoyJzkA:F5j7VQgg2po:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0-HxqoyJzkA:F5j7VQgg2po:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/0-HxqoyJzkA\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 02 Dec 2020 23:12:24 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fc81e1e037cbd00186137d3?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"6260898bb521a6b7be6e9d0f26126c32","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn95@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-48-885_a5368cb644757acf.webp","destWidth":2947,"destHeight":2210,"sourceBytes":294090,"destBytes":294090,"author":"insider@insider.com (Juliana Manjarrés)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5522ad14eab8ea85712860cb?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn72@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-826_6e682e8e30d1566c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5d277e4b2516e91f8f121fd4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn100@2020_6/2020/12/03/02-49-00-125_2941b982d32801fd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0-HxqoyJzkA:F5j7VQgg2po:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn43@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-49-02-288_c98f52d7bda52741.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0-HxqoyJzkA:F5j7VQgg2po:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn95@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-48-59-242_48187d200ca72f66.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0-HxqoyJzkA:F5j7VQgg2po:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn55@2020_6/2020/12/03/02-48-52-555_5062269c5d7498c4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/0-HxqoyJzkA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn40@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-48-55-390_d635faa015bd01db.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963710043},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","title":"'She's smart as hell': Biden stands by OMB director nominee Neera Tanden amid outcry from conservatives and progressives","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/neera-tanden-joe-biden-omb-director-budget-nominee-support-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fc50ca0037cbd0018612d83?format=jpeg\" alt=\"CAP President Neera Tanden moderates the &#34;Why Women&#39;s Economic Security Matters For All&#34; panel discussion at The Center For American Progress on September 18, 2014 in Washington, DC.\" height=\"854\" width=\"1280\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Neera Tanden.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Paul Morigi/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>President-elect Joe Biden stood by Neera Tanden, his nominee for director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/02/opinion/biden-interview-mcconnell-china-iran.html\">during an interview with The New York Times</a>.</li>\n<li>\"I think they're going to pick a couple of people just to fight [over] no matter what,\" Biden said of Senate Republicans.</li>\n<li>Tanden's nomination has attracted increased resistance from Republicans, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bidens-omb-pick-condemned-by-bernie-sanders-aligned-progressives-2020-11\">along with progressive activists</a> that she clashed with during the 2016 Democratic presidential primaries when she backed former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton over Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>President-elect Joe Biden in an interview with <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/02/opinion/biden-interview-mcconnell-china-iran.html\">The New York Times published</a> on Wednesday defended Neera Tanden, his nominee for director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, saying that Republicans opposed to her nomination were just trying \"to pick a fight.\"</p><p>When asked by Opinion columnist Thomas Friedman whether \"nasty tweets should be disqualifying in this day and age,\" Biden wasn't fazed by GOP criticism of Tanden's Twitter account, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/neera-tanden-biden-omb-nominee-delete-tweets-bashing-gop-senators-2020-12\">where she has been highly critical</a> of President Donald Trump and Republican legislators over the years.&#160;</p><p>\"That disqualifies almost every Republican senator and 90 percent of the administration,\" Biden responded. \"But by the way, she's smart as hell. Yeah, I think they're going to pick a couple of people just to fight [over] no matter what.\"</p><p>While Biden's foreign policy team included seasoned veterans like Secretary of State nominee Antony Blinken and US Ambassador to the United Nations Ambassador nominee Linda Thomas-Greenfield who <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/11/22/antony-blinken-named-secretary-state-biden-administration/6226556002/\">are likely to attract bipartisan support</a>, Tanden is expected to face a difficult Senate confirmation hearing.</p><p>Tanden, CEO of the Center for American Progress, the liberal think tank, has been a fixture in Washington DC for years. She was a longtime aide to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, starting with her work in the White House during the presidency of Bill Clinton, and would be the first Indian-American woman to lead the White House budget office.</p><p>However, her nomination has attracted increased resistance from Republicans, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bidens-omb-pick-condemned-by-bernie-sanders-aligned-progressives-2020-11\">along with progressive activists</a> who were aligned with Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/11/30/bernie-supporters-seethes-neera-tanden-441603\">whom she opposed</a> during the 2016 Democratic presidential primaries.</p><p>In the past, Tanden has referred to GOP Senate Majority Leader <a href=\"https://thehill.com/people/mitch-mcconnell\" data-nid=\"188280\">Mitch McConnell</a> (R-Ky.) as \"Moscow Mitch,\" a pejorative that many liberals used to link him to Trump and the Russia investigation. The tweet in question was recently deleted, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/dec/01/neera-tanden-deletes-tweets-office-of-management-and-budget-nominee\">according to the Guardian</a>.</p><p>This week, Republican Sen. John Cornyn of Texas described Tanden as \"radioactive\" and said that her nomination is&#160;\"really a misstep by the administration.\"</p><p>He added: \"It's pretty crazy to me to think that she can go back and … eliminate all the tweets that she's sent out over the last, whatever, months, years.\"</p><p>In preparation for the confirmation process, Tanden has already deleted over 1,000 tweets from her official account, <a href=\"https://www.thedailybeast.com/neera-tanden-mean-tweeted-gop-lawmakersuntil-she-needed-their-votes?ref=home\">according to The Daily Beast</a></p><p>The GOP currently controls the Senate 52-48. Democrats would need to win both of the January runoff elections in Georgia in order to create a 50-50 split and have Vice President-elect Kamala Harris break ties in favor of Biden's nominees. Otherwise, Senate Republicans will control the nomination process.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/neera-tanden-joe-biden-omb-director-budget-nominee-support-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=jxfSHwVQz_A:lmYZMapA8Ow:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=jxfSHwVQz_A:lmYZMapA8Ow:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jxfSHwVQz_A:lmYZMapA8Ow:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=jxfSHwVQz_A:lmYZMapA8Ow:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jxfSHwVQz_A:lmYZMapA8Ow:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=jxfSHwVQz_A:lmYZMapA8Ow:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=jxfSHwVQz_A:lmYZMapA8Ow:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jxfSHwVQz_A:lmYZMapA8Ow:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/jxfSHwVQz_A\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 02 Dec 2020 22:31:22 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fc8120a037cbd001861378b?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"5d23e668a38e8acd0aa058b67ce9e29a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn74@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-48-49-679_1b6f3e71792a6c36.webp","destWidth":1137,"destHeight":853,"sourceBytes":48788,"destBytes":48788,"author":"insider@insider.com (John L. Dorman)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fc50ca0037cbd0018612d83?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn59@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-02-962_9e4704c7f9c1cf2e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jxfSHwVQz_A:lmYZMapA8Ow:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn60@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-57-346_8bde7c2f531331f0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jxfSHwVQz_A:lmYZMapA8Ow:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn87@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-48-54-852_3e1584db7833e072.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jxfSHwVQz_A:lmYZMapA8Ow:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn4@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-57-086_789320daf2ddc64d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/jxfSHwVQz_A":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn84@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-896_c7e680d5a9c7081a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963710004},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","title":"What influencers should know before signing with a talent manager and red flags to look out for, according to industry experts","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-influencers-should-know-before-signing-with-a-talent-manager-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8f19c59e9fe4001900a620?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Black woman influencer\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.co.uk/detail/photo/woman-recording-makeup-tutorial-with-dslr-and-ring-royalty-free-image/1135361229\" target=\"_blank\">Youngoldman/Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Many influencers sign with managers to help grow their careers and land brand deals.</li>\n<li>But there are several things industry experts say influencers should known before signing with a manager and red flags to look out for.</li>\n<li>One red flag is a manager asking for an up-front fee or \"deposit,\" the experts said.</li>\n<li>\"You're never asked to pay a deposit,\" said Erin Cutler, a talent manager and the founder of the influencer talent-management agency Neon Rose.</li>\n<li>Here are the other factors influencer industry insiders say to consider before signing with a manager.</li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"http://newsletter.businessinsider.com/join/influencerdashboard\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"98017caaffd93628e1217254a790380a\">Subscribe to Business Insider's influencer newsletter</a>.</strong></li>\n</ul><p>When a talent-management firm called IQ Advantage reached out to influencers with flattering messages offering representation, many thought it was a good deal, they told Business Insider.</p><p>Influencers often sign with talent managers or agents to support their growing careers.</p><p>IQ Advantage pitched management services like reaching out to brands, negotiating deals, and building media kits. But there was a catch: a $299 \"deposit\" they had to pay up front.</p><p>That deposit should have been a red flag, six influencer industry experts told Business Insider. Instead of charging an up-front fee, talent managers typically earn a commission between 10% and 20%.</p><p>\"You're never asked to pay a deposit,\" said Erin Cutler, a talent manager and the founder of the influencer talent-management agency Neon Rose.&#160;</p><p>\"No agency would ever ask for a retainer, that's red flag number one,\" said Qianna Smith Bruneteau, the founder of the influencer trade organization the American Influencer Council.</p><p>Of the influencers who ended up paying IQ Advantage — which has now shut down — 13 told Business Insider that they felt the firm had failed to deliver on its promises. And only one of them was refunded the money (after disputing the charge on PayPal).</p><p><strong>Read the full story about IQ Advantage: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/influencers-say-talent-management-firm-iq-advantage-failed-on-promises-2020-11\">Influencers say a talent management firm run by a 21-year-old took hundreds of dollars from them but failed to deliver on promises. When we started asking questions, it shut down.</a></strong></p><p>With a cautionary tale like this, the first red flag was the deposit. But industry experts said there are other things influencers looking for representation should watch out for.</p><h3>Here are a few things influencers should consider before signing with any manager, according to industry insiders:</h3><ul><li><strong>Carefully consider if you are really ready for a manager. </strong>Signing with management, especially if an influencer is not yet a full-time creator, doesn't always make sense financially. \"We tell people all the time: You need to be working pretty heavily before, or at least significant enough to warrant an agent or a manager,\" said Lynsey Eaton, a cofounder of the talent management agency Estate Five.&#160;</li><li><strong>The manager-influencer relationship is supposed to be mutually beneficial.</strong> \"It's not a transactional process,\" said James Nord, the founder and CEO of Fohr, an influencer-marketing platform that connects brands and creators. \"It's a courtship. This person is essentially becoming part of your team.\"&#160;</li><li><strong>Ask questions about their process and how they work with influencers. </strong>When first considering signing with a talent management agency, influencers should ask questions like \"How quickly do you respond to emails?\" or \"What kind of transparency can I get into what you're doing?\" Nord said.&#160;&#160;</li><li><strong>Request references and case studies. </strong>Asking for references is an important first step, according to Nord. But go beyond the references they provide, since they're likely to recommend the most flattering reference, he added. Most agencies will also have a roster of influencers, either as a document or included on a website, that prospective influencers can reach out to. Case studies that demonstrate past partnerships are also helpful, said content creator and influencer coach Lissette Calveiro.</li><li><strong>Check out the agency's website and social-media presence.&#160;</strong>Do they have an active, authentic social-media presence? Do they have any articles written about them or their work (that weren't paid for)? These are a few things that Calveiro also suggested influencers look at before signing anything.</li><li><strong>Be wary of mass emails that feel generic.</strong> Managers don't typically send out mass emails to influencers looking for new talent, according to Neon Rose's Cutler. \"If it's not personalized, that's a big red flag,\" said Calveiro, who had been reached out to herself by IQ Advantage.</li><li><strong>Never pay a deposit and avoid cash apps like PayPal, CashApp, Zelle, or Venmo. </strong>Not only are deposits a red flag, according to experts, but the AIC's Smith Bruneteau also advises that influencers get as much banking information as possible so that if needed, they can pursue legal action, such as through small-claims court.</li></ul><h1><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/influencers-say-talent-management-firm-iq-advantage-failed-on-promises-2020-11\">Subscribe to Business Insider to read the full story.</a></h1><div src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=s-qIM5ryGrg:zEu02erpIqQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=s-qIM5ryGrg:zEu02erpIqQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=s-qIM5ryGrg:zEu02erpIqQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=s-qIM5ryGrg:zEu02erpIqQ:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=s-qIM5ryGrg:zEu02erpIqQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=s-qIM5ryGrg:zEu02erpIqQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/s-qIM5ryGrg\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 02 Dec 2020 20:39:03 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8f19c59e9fe4001900a620?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"c55ef533ce62c985b824ad9a78d5b44e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn8@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-48-37-481_0670af6613047a9c.webp","destWidth":2000,"destHeight":1500,"sourceBytes":100724,"destBytes":100724,"author":"sbradley@businessinsider.com (Sydney Bradley)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f8f19c59e9fe4001900a620?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn8@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-48-37-481_0670af6613047a9c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=s-qIM5ryGrg:zEu02erpIqQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn12@2020_6/2020/12/03/02-48-56-098_5391ae3ea5f4d86a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=s-qIM5ryGrg:zEu02erpIqQ:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn71@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-52-054_d4b830f47594d047.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=s-qIM5ryGrg:zEu02erpIqQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn4@2020_6/2020/12/03/02-48-53-111_c920769d6c62e1ce.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/s-qIM5ryGrg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn7@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-930_f078cf79aef61c49.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963710044},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","title":"Billionaires Steven Cohen and Dan Sundheim just struck a $700 million deal to take a collectibles company private — and it could be a brilliant move into an increasingly popular niche market","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/steve-cohen-collectors-universe-collectables-dan-sundehim-nat-turner-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fb42c7f402d49001924f604?format=jpeg\" alt=\"steve cohen\" height=\"2332\" width=\"3110\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>FILE PHOTO: Hedge fund manager Steven A. Cohen, founder and chairman of SAC Capital Advisors, responds to a question during a one-on-one interview session at the SkyBridge Alternatives (SALT) Conference in Las Vegas, Nevada May 11, 2011.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Steve Marcus/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><strong>In a deal involving multiple billionaires, Steven A. Cohen is teaming with Dan Sundheim and Nat Turner on a <a href=\"https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2020/11/30/2136654/0/en/Collectors-Universe-to-be-Acquired-by-Investor-Group-Led-by-Entrepreneur-and-Collector-Nat-Turner-for-Approximately-700-Million.html\">$700 million deal</a> to take Collectors Universe private.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>The November 30 deal brings together Cohen Private Ventures and D1 Capital Partners with </strong><strong>Turner, an avid sports-card collector, in a bid for the collectibles authentication company, whose shares have tripled in value during 2020.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>Investing in sports collectibles and trading cards has been on the rise in recent years, Robb Petrozzo, </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rally-prive-porter-to-sell-stock-in-hermes-birkin-bags-2020-2\"><strong>cofounder and chief product officer of rival investment platform Rally</strong></a><strong>, told Business Insider.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>Petrozzo said this deal has the potential to expand Collectors Universe into a \"full-service platform\" that can support the entire collecting journey, \"from the data that validates the creation of new products all the way through the sale in the primary and secondary market.\"</strong></li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Collecting assets, such as sports memorabilia and trading cards, is having a moment — like, a huge moment. A new deal to take collectibles-authentication service company Collectors Universe private for $700 million proves it.&#160;</p><p>The deal <a href=\"https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2020/11/30/2136654/0/en/Collectors-Universe-to-be-Acquired-by-Investor-Group-Led-by-Entrepreneur-and-Collector-Nat-Turner-for-Approximately-700-Million.html\">was announced on November 30</a>, with Cohen Private Ventures, the firm that handles the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/steve-cohen-net-worth-billionaire-house-real-estate-career-mets-2019-12\">personal investments of billionaire Steven A.Cohen</a>, teaming up with <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/dan-sundheim-profile-d1-capital-net-worth-art-performance-assets-2020-10\">Dan Sundheim's investment firm D1 Capital Partners</a>&#160;and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nat-turner-flatiron-health-interview-2018-3\">entrepreneur Nat Turner</a> to take Collectors Universe private for $75.25 a share.&#160;</p><p>Sundheim, who <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/dan-sundheim-profile-d1-capital-net-worth-art-performance-assets-2020-10-1029646279\">Business Insider's Bradley Sacks and Alex Morell likened to</a> the \"LeBron James of investing,\" specializes in investing in categories such as technology, media, and real estate. Meanwhile, Turner, besides being a serial investor who cofounded the health startup Flatiron, sold in 2018 for <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/roche-acquires-flatiron-health-for-19-billion-2018-2\">$1.9 billion</a>, is also an avid sports-card collector.&#160;</p><p>\"Collecting sports cards and connecting with like-minded hobbyists has been a lifelong passion,\"&#160; Turner said in the press release. \"We are committed to bringing the resources and expertise necessary to expand the Company's operational capacity and technological capabilities, while enhancing the accuracy and consistency for which Collectors Universe is known.\"</p><p>Collectors Universe, which authenticates and grades memorabilia, including sports cards and vintage autographs, saw its <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-11-30/steve-cohen-and-d1-capital-team-up-to-buy-collectors-universe?sref=BLKWHazc\">shares triple</a> during the pandemic, with hobbies like collecting an ideal match for the pandemic-era trend of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/wealthy-americans-doing-hobbies-alone-already-reshaping-economy-2020-6\">solitary leisure</a>.&#160;</p><p>Cohen Venture Partners and D1 Capital Partners declined to comment when reached by Business Insider. Nat Turner didn't immediately respond to a request for comment from Business Insider.&#160;</p><h2>This deal has the potential to legitimize sports and trading cards as an investment asset, according to an expert&#160;</h2><p>Robb Petrozzo, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rally-prive-porter-to-sell-stock-in-hermes-birkin-bags-2020-2\">cofounder and chief product officer of the investment platform Rally</a>, told Business Insider that buying memorabilia, specifically within the sports category, has been on the rise in the past few years, and the overall toy category has proven to be a class that is both better yielding and more \"interesting\" than standard investment funds.&#160;</p><p>\"There is this emotional connection and passionate investment from something that you recognized from childhood or from a good moment in your life,\" Petrozzo told Business Insider.</p><p>This latest deal, Petrozzo said, speaks to the potential of the sports card and memorabilia space, \"not just in terms of collecting, but in terms of legitimizing the data associated with the asset class, the investment-worthiness of memorabilia, and the potential mass-market opportunity for hobbyists and institutions alike.\"</p><p>With this deal, Petrozzo said Collectors Universe has the potential to expand from primarily grading and cataloging into a \"full-service platform\" that can support the entire collecting journey, \"from the data that validates the creation of new products all the way through the sale in the primary and secondary market.\"</p><p>\"The big-name, low-population early cards in mint condition are still where the big money goes,\" he said, citing such names as Kobe Bryant, Mickey Mantle, LeBron James, and Michael Jordan. In a volatile market, he said, prices tend to stabilize faster for those names, even when they see corrections, as collectors quickly buy them on the way down, or on the dip. Original Pokemon sets and Michael Jordan Rookie cards are continuing to see strength, with 300%-plus returns since the start of 2020, Petrozzo said.&#160;</p><p>Over time, many childhood items become hard to find, which also increases their investment value, he said, pointing to wrestling memorabilia as an example:&#160;</p><p>\"What you'll see is that a Hulk Hogan mint-condition rookie card from his WWF days will skyrocket in value,\" Petrozzo said. \"What's happened is that all the figures and elements, all those ancillary items from his rise to fame in sealed condition are extremely hard to find.\"&#160;</p><p>\"The same collectors who are buying mint-condition cards might now be sitting on a $20,000 or $30,000 Hulk Hogan card,\" he continued.&#160;</p><p>And though collecting toys and memorabilia as an asset class is still in its \"first inning,\" Petrozzo said he expects the investment value of this asset class to only rise. It seems Steven A. Cohen is betting on that, too.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/steve-cohen-collectors-universe-collectables-dan-sundehim-nat-turner-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/nT03AYkXzmk\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 02 Dec 2020 20:09:52 You can replace it and surprise him with your own sweet message, too.</p>\n\tVitamin-infused body wash\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ced84b911e20508931cc3f7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"necessaire\" height=\"562\" width=\"750\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Necessaire Instagram</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://shop-links.co/1716512831753250805\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow nofollow nofollow nofollow nofollow sponsored\">Gift the Necessaire Body Wash, $25</a></h3><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/necessaire-body-wash-lotion-review\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">Gender-neutral personal care brand Necessaire</a> treats the body with clean, sustainable ingredients and vitamins. He'll love using the Eucalyptus or Sandalwood body washes to nourish his skin without stripping it of moisture.&#160;</p>\n\t'Sleep' glasses to reduce eye fatigue\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ced846911e2050f60697807?format=jpeg\" alt=\"felix gray\" height=\"562\" width=\"750\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Felix Gray Instagram</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://felixgray.ntaf.net/c/196318/614444/10016?u=https%3A%2F%2Fshopfelixgray.com%2Fmen%2Fsleepglasses\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow nofollow nofollow nofollow nofollow sponsored\">Gift a pair of Felix Gray Sleep Glasses, from $145</a></h3><p>The blue light that comes off our screens affects sleep, so rather than deny him access entirely from his phone or laptop before bed, gift him <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/felix-gray-sleep-glasses-review\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">these blue light-blocking glasses</a>. readerx29/cdn80@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-59-197_d579fd992c46f339.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ced851a11e205080620e206?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn67@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-49-02-658_eb33c96e39e49906.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dc58d943afd3770e30b2075?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn4@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-58-462_1971dee7d2aa0994.webp","https://i.insider.com/5cf57ce811e2051ab42e9225?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn6@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-51-245_48ff80837ae5cb0a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1JoLKVBgyWA:Spdf87ET6rU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn47@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-49-00-435_8cd4a735b0e5a2bc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1JoLKVBgyWA:Spdf87ET6rU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn39@2020_6/2020/12/03/02-48-51-029_fed05962863ff6a0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1JoLKVBgyWA:Spdf87ET6rU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn68@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-48-54-775_07d8a85b96132538.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/1JoLKVBgyWA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn40@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-49-01-301_5ebad57255385d6c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963709997},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:29","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:29","title":"Mystery solved: NASA confirmed the space object that just zipped past Earth is a 1960s rocket booster","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-mystery-object-flying-past-earth-1960s-rocket-booster-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fc7fba050e71a0011558868?format=jpeg\" alt=\"surveyor moon mission lander\" height=\"780\" width=\"1041\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A model of the Surveyor lander.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=7783\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/JPL-Caltech</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>NASA has confirmed that a mysterious object that just flew past Earth is the dead booster of a 1960s Centaur rocket.</li>\n<li>Earth's gravity briefly captured the booster this year, causing it to loop the planet twice before returning to an orbit around the sun.</li>\n<li>Scientists confirmed that the object was a Centaur booster by comparing its electromagnetic fingerprint to that of a known Centaur booster in space.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A mysterious object zipped past Earth on Tuesday, coming within 32,000 miles of our planet. After months of head-scratching, scientists finally identified this visitor from beyond.</p><p>It's not an asteroid. It's not a comet. It's not an alien spaceship. On Wednesday, NASA confirmed that the object, formerly known as 2020 SO, is the booster of a Centaur rocket that launched in 1966.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fc7f9aa037cbd0018613705?format=jpeg\" alt=\"centaur rocket second stage\" height=\"1536\" width=\"2048\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A researcher prepares a Centaur 6A second-stage rocket for a series of tests in the Space Power Chambers&#39; vacuum tank at NASA&#39;s Lewis Research Center in 1964.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://images.nasa.gov/details-GRC-1964-C-71099\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The rocket carried the Surveyor 2 mission, which was set to land on the moon, but went into a death spiral when one of its thrusters failed to fire with the others. Surveyor 2 crashed into the lunar surface, but the rocket booster had separated from the spacecraft shortly after pushing it towards its lunar destination. The booster then drifted, unseen, into the abyss of space.</p><p>Now Earth's gravity has briefly captured the rocket booster once again, like a tiny moon orbiting our planet. It's set to loop Earth twice before escaping the planet's pull in March 2021. Then it will continue on a new orbit around the sun.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fc7ec9b037cbd001861369a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"2020 so rocket booster orbit\" height=\"670\" width=\"1168\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The orbit of 2020 SO, sped up a million times faster than real time.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=7783\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/JPL-Caltech</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Its Tuesday flyby was the dead booster's closest approach to our planet.</p><p>A telescope on the Hawaiian island Maui first spotted the new space object in September. Its orbit seemed unnatural, following unusually close to Earth and remaining within the same plane as our planet. Most asteroids have tilted orbits, dipping above or below Earth as they journey around the sun.</p><p>\"I was suspicious immediately,\" Paul Chodas, director of NASA's Center for Near-Earth Object Studies (CNEOS), <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/01/science/nasa-rocket-orbit.html\">told the New York Times</a>.</p><p>Like Chodas, many scientists had suspected that this object was the Surveyor 2 booster, since reverse simulations of its orbit placed it so close to Earth in September 1966 that it could have easily come from our planet.</p><p>To test the theory, scientists used a NASA telescope on Hawaii's Maunakea to watch 2020 SO as it flew past Earth. They logged the object's spectrum data — wavelengths of electromagnetic radiation that act like fingerprints for objects in space. Different wavelengths represent different chemical compounds.</p><p>Scientists then compared the 2020 SO spectra to that of a known Centaur rocket booster, which has been orbiting Earth since it launched a satellite in 1971. The fingerprints matched.</p><p>\"This conclusion was the result of a tremendous team effort,\" Vishnu Reddy, a planetary scientist at the University of Arizona who led the study, said in a <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/feature/new-data-confirm-2020-so-to-be-the-upper-centaur-rocket-booster-from-the-1960-s\">press release</a>. \"We were finally able to solve this mystery.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-mystery-object-flying-past-earth-1960s-rocket-booster-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_Y73NdKZRU4:nkQPDcJY9VQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/_Y73NdKZRU4\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 02 Dec 2020 20:56:14 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fc7fbb150e71a001155886a?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"ea35c6e5363a4888b6dc5d6d7b18ba55","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn47@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-49-767_a8f072c658d7ee50.webp","destWidth":1898,"destHeight":1423,"sourceBytes":402802,"destBytes":402802,"author":"mmcfalljohnsen@businessinsider.com (Morgan McFall-Johnsen)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fc7fba050e71a0011558868?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn68@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-59-935_e6b3a5bc1e15b61d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fc7f9aa037cbd0018613705?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn83@2020_6/2020/12/03/02-49-00-240_05caf85fc0bdf98c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fc7ec9b037cbd001861369a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn31@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-58-870_1460aeba87978cd0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_Y73NdKZRU4:nkQPDcJY9VQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn63@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-55-737_b42494056267a52a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_Y73NdKZRU4:nkQPDcJY9VQ:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn64@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-48-632_ef26fa72bbea483d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_Y73NdKZRU4:nkQPDcJY9VQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn31@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-545_132a957a0005f71c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/_Y73NdKZRU4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn72@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-48-53-568_03629f78bebc1543.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963709995},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","title":"Interpol warns that organized crime groups will likely try to steal 'liquid gold' COVID vaccines as well as peddle fake doses","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/organized-crime-threatens-covid-19-vaccines-interpol-warns-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f71dadb74fe5b0018a8db55?format=jpeg\" alt=\"vaccine\" height=\"1843\" width=\"2852\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Interpol warned agencies to be on high alert for fraudulent vaccines and cyber threats.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Siphiwe Sibeko/Pool via AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Law enforcement agencies should be prepared for organized crime networks to try to steal COVID-19 vaccines, Interpol said in a statement Wednesday.&#160;</li>\n<li>The organization warned that criminal groups will likely attempt to infiltrate supply chains and sell fraudulent vaccines.&#160;</li>\n<li>The pandemic has \"already triggered unprecedented opportunistic and predatory criminal behaviour,\" according to Interpol.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Multiple COVID-19 vaccines from firms including Pfizer and Moderna have proven highly effective and are set to be distributed in massive quantities over the coming months once approved by regulators. But, as if obtaining, storing, and distributing millions of doses wasn't challenging enough, countries around the world will likely need to overcome yet another hurdle: organized crime.</p><p>Interpol, the International Criminal Police Organization, issued a <a href=\"https://www.interpol.int/en/News-and-Events/News/2020/INTERPOL-warns-of-organized-crime-threat-to-COVID-19-vaccines\">statement</a> Wednesday to law enforcement agencies in its 194 member countries alerting them of the threat that organized crime networks pose to the distribution of COVID-19 vaccines.</p><p>As countries roll out vaccines, organized crime networks will likely attempt to penetrate supply chains and steal doses, the group warned, adding that law enforcement should be on the lookout for people passing off fake vaccines online.&#160;</p><p>\"Criminal networks will also be targeting unsuspecting members of the public via fake websites and false cures, which could pose a significant risk to their health, even their lives,\" said Jürgen Stock, Interpol's secretary-general. \"It is essential that law enforcement is as prepared as possible for what will be an onslaught of all types of criminal activity linked to the COVID-19 vaccine, which is why Interpol has issued this global warning,\"</p><p>According to the group, the pandemic has \"already triggered unprecedented opportunistic and predatory criminal behavior.\" Interpol also said that, as global travel slowly returns, criminal entities will likely ramp up production and distribution of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/global-black-market-for-negative-covid-test-results-2020-11\">fraudulent COVID-19 testing kits</a>.</p><p>The alert comes as public health officials around the globe evaluate multiple COVID-19 vaccines that recently completed trials and appear to be safe and effective. On Wednesday, the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pfizer-and-biontech-covid-19-vaccines-approved-by-uk-regulator-2020-11\">UK authorized Pfizer and BioNTech's vaccine</a> for emergency use, and other countries are expected to follow suit.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-pharmacies-hospitals-could-profit-from-covid-19-vaccine-2020-11?r=tl-sub\">Pharmacies, doctor's offices and hospitals are gearing up to give coronavirus vaccines to millions of Americans. Here's how they're preparing and how much they stand to profit along the way.</a></em></p><p>Over the last several months, there have been instances of groups and indviduals attempting to illegally profit off of the pandemic by <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/3m-n95-mask-maker-accuses-amazon-seller-of-20x-markup-2020-6\">selling personal protective equipment at inflated prices</a>, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/florida-man-buys-lamborghini-charged-coronavirus-covid-ppp-funds-huracan-2020-7\">taking advantage of the federal government's Paycheck Protection Program</a>, and other schemes.&#160;</p><p>As news of multiple promising COVID-19 vaccine candidates broke in November, Interpol released an initial <a href=\"https://www.interpol.int/en/News-and-Events/News/2020/COVID-19-crime-INTERPOL-issues-new-guidelines-for-law-enforcement\">statement</a> warning law enforcement agencies of the likelihood that organized crime would target storage facilities and supply chains, likening the forthcoming vaccines to \"liquid gold to organized crime networks.\"</p><p>But, according to the agency, one of the main threats posed by organized crime during the pandemic has been to people's data and devices.</p><p>In Wednesday's memo, Interpol noted an increasing volume of COVID-19-related scams, and recommended that people be extra careful when shopping for medicines or medical equipment online. Of 3,000 online pharmacies the group suspected of selling illicit devices and products, more than half also contained cyber threats.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on Levin)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f71dadb74fe5b0018a8db55?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn63@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-53-802_7eb8c440726c6a07.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-49-00-176_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Mua8cVgI2DM:WncULqv9waw:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn55@2020_4/2020/12/03/02-49-02-929_7d54f9ae1e4079ea.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Mua8cVgI2DM:WncULqv9waw:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn3@2020_2/2020/12/03/02-48-55-237_b3d2d8f4f525dc98.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_3/2020/12/03/02-48-56-007_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Mua8cVgI2DM:WncULqv9waw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn23@2020_5/2020/12/03/02-48-50-717_e4fc0095c2798907.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Mua8cVgI2DM":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn83@2020_1/2020/12/03/02-48-52-897_b603dba6bb6229ca.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1606963710017},{"createdTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","updatedTime":"2020-12-03 10:48:30","title":"Top US general says 2 decades of brutal fighting in Afghanistan has achieved only a 'modicum of success'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/milley-decades-in-afghanistan-achieved-a-modicum-of-success-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fc7e19d037cbd0018613629?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Mark Milley\" height=\"512\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Mark Milley.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Mark Milley said Wednesday that the US has achieved a \"modicum of success\" after nearly two decades \"of consistent effort\" in Afghanistan.</li>\n<li>The problem is that for the past few years, the situation in Afghanistan has been a \"strategic stalemate,\" Milley added.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Mark Milley said Wednesday that the US has achieved a \"modicum of success\" after nearly two decades of fighting in Afghanistan.</p><p>\"We believe now that after 20 years, two decades of consistent effort, that we he have achieved a modicum of success,\" Milley, the highest-ranking US military officer, said Wednesday during a virtual event at the Brookings Institution think tank.</p><p>The US has invested tremendous amounts of blood and treasure in Afghanistan. Since 2001, more than 2,400 US troops have been killed there, and almost 21,000 have been wounded. The US has also spent close to a $1 trillion on the conflict.</p><p>Milley said that the US went to Afghanistan \"to ensure that Afghanistan never again became a platform for a terroristic strike against the United States,\" referring to the September 11, 2001, attacks in the US.</p><p>\"To a large measure, at least to date, we have been successful in preventing that from happening again,\" Milley added.</p><p>The problem is that for the past few years, the situation in Afghanistan has been a \"strategic stalemate,\" he said.</p><p>\"The government of Afghanistan was never going to militarily defeat the Taliban, and the Taliban, as long as we were supporting the government of Afghanistan, was never going to militarily defeat the regime,\" he said. \"So you've had a condition of strategic stalemate.\"</p><p>Milley argued that the only real solution is a negotiated settlement, an approach that has been gaining momentum since the US and Taliban signed an agreement earlier this year.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fc7ea12037cbd0018613681?format=jpeg\" alt=\"US army navy air force graves Arlington Afghanistan Iraq\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Graves of US service members in Arlington National Cemetery.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Saul Loeb/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Wednesday announced that the Taliban and the Afghanistan government agreed to develop an official framework for formal peace negotiations, which the two sides had been unable to do because of continued violence in the country.</p><p>\"We congratulate both sides on their perseverance and willingness to find common ground,\" Pompeo said in a statement. \"This achievement demonstrates that the Afghan Islamic Republic and Taliban are serious, able to overcome differences, and ready to deal with difficult issues.\"</p><p>\"The United States, along with most of the international community, will continue to support the peace process in pursuit of this goal,\" Pompeo added. \"As negotiations on a political roadmap and permanent ceasefire begin, we will also work hard with all sides in pursuit of a serious reduction of violence and ceasefire.\"<strong><br></strong></p><p>This year, the US has steadily pulled thousands of US troops out of Afghanistan. In mid-November, new acting Secretary of Defense Chris Miller announced that the US would further reduce troop levels from 4,500 to 2,500 by mid-January.</p><p>During the announcement, Miller stressed that the US remains committed to the fight against terrorism, stating that \"if the forces of terror, instability, division, and hate begin a deliberate campaign to disrupt our efforts, we stand ready to apply the capabilities required to thwart them.\"</p><p>President Donald Trump and President-elect Joe Biden have both signaled a desire to end the decades-long war in Afghanistan.</p><p>Trump has campaigned on completely pulling troops out of conflict zones and significantly reducing US military involvement in the Middle East. Biden has offered to withdraw the lion's share of combat troops but leave some residual forces behind.</p><p>\"With the blessings of Providence in the coming year, we will finish this generational war, and bring our men and women home,\" Miller said in November. \"We will protect our children from the heavy burden and toll of perpetual war.\"</p><p>Milley said Wednesday that what happens is going to be up to the new administration.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a morning and sell a million dollars in the afternoon, I can do that in an ETF format,\" he said.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong>O'Leary added that if the SEC approved a crypto ETF, more institutional investors would buy bitcoin.</strong></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\"><strong>Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</strong></a><strong style=\"color: #222222;\">.</strong></li></ul><hr><p>Shark Tank investor Kevin O'Leary told <a href=\"https://podcasts.apple.com/lv/podcast/441-kevin-oleary-on-alternative-assets/id1434060078?i=1000500956977\">The Pomp Podcast</a> on Tuesday that <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/btc-usd\">bitcoin</a> is too volatile and illiquid for his portfolio, but he would consider owning a basket of cryptocurrencies in an ETF.&#160;&#160;</p><p>O'Leary has created multiple ETFs as the chairman of O'Shares, and he said that a crypto ETF could be the most liquid way to buy and sell bitcoin. The investor said that right now there are too many fees associated with getting in and out of bitcoin, but he does own a little bit of the coin right now.</p><p>\"Give me the top 7 cryptocurrencies, put them into an ETF wrapper, and let me invest in it with liquidity so that if I want to buy a million dollars of it in the morning and sell a million dollars in the afternoon, I can do that in an ETF format,\" he said.&#160;</p><p>He also told host Anthony Pompliano that doesn't believe there will be only one successful cryptocurrency, and coins like <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/eth-usd\">Ethereum</a> will benefit when more investors see cryptos as stores of value and potentially a medium of exchange. Whereas equity investors can buy a \"basket of stocks,\" it's harder for crypto investors to load up on multiple coins. An ETF would solve this problem.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/options-trading-how-investors-can-protect-tech-heavy-portfolios-nasdaq-2020-12\" data-analytics-position=\"6\" data-analytics-module=\"\">The creator of a new volatility index for the Nasdaq 100 shares how investors can protect portfolios loaded with tech names — and explains why he thinks it's superior to the VIX</a></em></p><p>Also, the seal of approval from the SEC that the ETF would require may convince more institutional investors to buy bitcoin, he said. O'Leary said institutional support is \"slowly creeping\" into the bitcoin market, but many investors are still hesitant without \"clearance from the regulators.\"&#160;</p><p>\"If tomorrow morning we woke up and the SEC said you can create an ETF with bitcoin and we think bitcoin is legitimate payment system and storage of wealth, not only would it go up, you'd have a lot of people like me investing in it, because I'd say ok, I'll give it a 5% weighting,\" added O'Leary.</p><p>Fortunately for O'Leary, the prospect of a crypto ETF may not be far out. In October,<a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/news/cryptocurrency-etf-under-consideration-sec-jay-clayton-says-2020-10-1029690330\"> SEC Chairman James Clayton said the SEC is working on regulations</a> that may one day authorize the use of cryptocurrency ETFs.&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/shark-tank-investor-kevin-oleary-says-he-would-buy-a-crypto-etf-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=R-33Q_Jm8kc:gPD38w5ddgk:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a
